title: What does it mean when a writ of Execution filed is partially satisfied?
question: What does it mean when a writ of Execution filed is partially satisfied? The question is in relation to a default judgement for a credit card that was discharged in a Chapter 7 bankruptcy.
answers: To properly answer your question, I would need a chronology of events. It almost sounds like you are claiming that the writ of Execution was processed AFTER you filed the Bankruptcy and received a discharge. If this is the case, a Creditor has continued to collect upon a debt that was discharged in Bankruptcy, which would be a violation of your rights. You should investigate whether money or property was taken from your wages or financial accounts after you filed the Bankruptcy, then discuss this situation with a qualified Bankruptcy Attorney in your area. If the money was taken after you filed Bankruptcy, a telephone call to the Creditor would most likely result in a refund check coming to you along with additional fees for the Attorney making the call. Of course, if the money or assets were taken prior to the filing of the Bankruptcy case, that would require further discussion as to whether or not you would be entitled to a refund. Best of Luck to you.

A judge issues a writ of execution after a party to a lawsuit, presumably your creditor, has obtained a judgment. The writ is issued to the winning party, and delivered by the creditor to the Sheriff for execution on a bank deposit or to an employer by way of a wage garnishment. If only part of the debt was collected in this fashion, then the writ of execution has been "partially" satisfied, or, in other words, partially paid.
Questions come to mind about whether the funds were collected and the writ of execution was "executed" anytime within 90 days before your bankruptcy was filed up until anytime after your bankruptcy was filed and discharged, and thereafter, as well. It is possible to get your money back and have your attorney fees paid. Or, was the judgment obtained in an adversary proceeding related to your bankruptcy? Did you have an attorney file your bankruptcy for you? Did you include this creditor in your Bankruptcy schedules of debt? There are so many things to talk about that you need to sit down with your bankruptcy attorney, if you had one, or with an experienced local attorney to see whether your rights have been violated and whether you have any remedies available to recover money that "partially satisfied" the credit card debt. Then you will know whether the balance of the credit card debt was also discharged or whether you are still vulnerable. Just to increase your comfort level, debt that is actually discharged in a bankruptcy cannot subsequently be collected. The rest of the questions have to do with the timing of the collection activity that resulted in a partial recovery by the creditor. I hope you seek counsel and wish you a Happy New Year. Being debt free is a great way to start a New Year! Take care!

Once a creditor is listed in Chapter 7 Bankruptcy, they will be discharged. (Unless it is a debt that is specifically non-dischargable). To properly answer your questions and address your concerns, the best way to handle this is with an in person consultation with an experienced CA Bankruptcy attorney. Use AVVO's Find a Lawyer tool to select a qualified attorney. Good luck.
If a debt was discharged, it cannot be collected. The writ is not going to be satisfied.
